title: Why does xylophone start with x? - Quora

response.answer_text: A xylophone is an array of wooden blocks that you whack with hammers, The word comes from two Greek words… “ξυλον”Spelled “xi-upsilon-lambda-omicron-nu”Romanised to “xylon”pronounced “zi-lon” to rhyme with “pylon” and “nylon”and meaning "wood"And “φωνη”Spelled “phi-omega-nu-eta”Romanised to “phone”pronounced “fone” to rhyme with “bone”, “loan” and “drone”and meaning "voice” or “sound"…and the whole word thus translates to “wooden sound”. So, to finally answer your question… The Greek word “ξυλον” starts with the Greek letter “ξ” (or “Ξ” in upper case) and when we transliterate that letter into English it becomes the letter “x”.

XYLOPHONE xylo- is derived from Greek xulon and -phone represents Greek phōnē, "voice, sound," the same element found in words such as telephone, microphone, and megaphone. Xulon - Greek - pertaining to wood. In this case the wooden tuned blocks that make up the Xylophone.
